      Comprehensive Guide: Time Domain to s-Domain Circuit Conversion

      Table of Contents

      1. Overview and Order of Operations
      2. The Standard Problem Progression
      3. Component Transformation Equations
      4. Step 1: Time Domain Circuit to s-Domain Circuit
      5. Step 2: Apply KVL/KCL to s-Domain Circuit
      6. Step 3: Derive Differential Equations from s-Domain
      7. Step 4: Setup for Laplace Transform
      8. Alternative Path: Differential Equation First
      9. Working Backwards: Inverse Operations
      10. Complete Worked Examples
      11. Tips and Tricks
      12. Common Pitfalls

      Overview and Order of Operations

      This guide covers TWO distinct paths for circuit analysis using Laplace transforms. Understanding the order is critical:

      PATH A: Direct s-Domain Transformation (Most Common in Exams) 

        graph TD
    A[Step 1: Time Domain Circuit] --> B[Step 2: Convert to s-Domain Circuit]
    B --> C[Step 3: Apply KVL/KCL in s-Domain]
    C --> D[Step 4: s-Domain Algebraic Equation]
    D --> E[Step 5: Solve for V_s or I_s]
    E --> F[Step 6: Apply Inverse Laplace Transform]
    F --> G[Step 7: Time Domain Solution v_t or i_t]
    
    style A fill:#ffebee
    style B fill:#fff3e0
    style C fill:#e1f5ff
    style D fill:#e8f5e9
    style E fill:#f3e5f5
    style F fill:#fff9c4
    style G fill:#c8e6c9

      Key Point: This path goes directly to s-domain, then applies circuit laws. You get an algebraic equation in sss, NOT a differential equation.

      PATH B: Differential Equation First (Alternative Method) 

        graph TD
    A[Step 1: Time Domain Circuit] --> B[Step 2: Apply KVL/KCL in Time Domain]
    B --> C[Step 3: Substitute Component Equations]
    C --> D[Step 4: Derive Differential Equation]
    D --> E[Step 5: Apply Laplace Transform]
    E --> F[Step 6: s-Domain Algebraic Equation]
    F --> G[Step 7: Solve for V_s or I_s]
    G --> H[Step 8: Apply Inverse Laplace Transform]
    H --> I[Step 9: Time Domain Solution]
    
    style A fill:#ffebee
    style D fill:#ffe0b2
    style E fill:#fff9c4
    style I fill:#c8e6c9

      Key Point: This path derives a differential equation in time domain FIRST, then transforms it.

      The Standard Problem Progression

      Based on your description, here is the typical exam question format:

      Problem Format

      Given:

      • Time domain circuit diagram
      • Component values (R, L, C)
      • Source functions vs(t)v_s(t)vs​(t) or is(t)i_s(t)is​(t)

      Part 1: Convert to s-Domain

      • Transform all components to s-domain equivalents
      • Draw the s-domain circuit diagram

      Part 2: Find Equation Using s-Domain Circuit

      • Apply KVL or KCL to the s-domain circuit
      • Obtain algebraic equation in terms of sss

      Part 3: Initial Conditions Given

      • You are NOW given: vC(0)v_C(0)vC​(0), iL(0)i_L(0)iL​(0), etc.
      • Incorporate these into your s-domain equation
      • Solve for V(s)V(s)V(s) or I(s)I(s)I(s)

      Part 4: Inverse Transform

      • Apply inverse Laplace transform
      • Find v(t)v(t)v(t) or i(t)i(t)i(t)

      Critical Clarification on “Differential Equations”

      IMPORTANT: When you go Time Domain → s-Domain Circuit → KVL/KCL, you get an ALGEBRAIC equation in sss, NOT a differential equation.

      You only get a differential equation if you:

      • Start in time domain and apply KVL/KCL there (PATH B), OR
      • Take your s-domain algebraic equation and inverse transform it back (which is backwards)

      The confusion: In PATH A, you can think of the s-domain algebraic equation as the “Laplace transform of the differential equation,” but you never explicitly write the differential equation.

      Component Transformation Equations

      Complete Time Domain to s-Domain Table

      ComponentTime Domains-Domain Impedance Z(s)Initial Condition (when given later)
      ResistorvR(t)=R⋅i(t)v_R(t) = R \cdot i(t)vR​(t)=R⋅i(t)ZR=RZ_R = RZR​=RNone
      CapacitoriC(t)=CdvC(t)dti_C(t) = C \frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}iC​(t)=CdtdvC​(t)​ZC=1sCZ_C = \frac{1}{sC}ZC​=sC1​Add voltage source vC(0)s\frac{v_C(0)}{s}svC​(0)​ in series
      InductorvL(t)=LdiL(t)dtv_L(t) = L \frac{di_L(t)}{dt}vL​(t)=LdtdiL​(t)​ZL=sLZ_L = sLZL​=sLAdd voltage source LiL(0)Li_L(0)LiL​(0) in series OR current source iL(0)s\frac{i_L(0)}{s}siL​(0)​ in parallel
      Voltage Sourcevs(t)v_s(t)vs​(t)N/AVs(s)=L{vs(t)}V_s(s) = \mathcal{L}\{v_s(t)\}Vs​(s)=L{vs​(t)}
      Current Sourceis(t)i_s(t)is​(t)N/AIs(s)=L{is(t)}I_s(s) = \mathcal{L}\{i_s(t)\}Is​(s)=L{is​(t)}

      Key Time-Domain Component Equations

      Resistor

      vR(t)=R⋅iR(t)v_R(t) = R \cdot i_R(t)vR​(t)=R⋅iR​(t)

      iR(t)=vR(t)Ri_R(t) = \frac{v_R(t)}{R}iR​(t)=RvR​(t)​

      Capacitor

      iC(t)=CdvC(t)dti_C(t) = C \frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}iC​(t)=CdtdvC​(t)​

      vC(t)=1C∫0tiC(τ)dτ+vC(0)v_C(t) = \frac{1}{C}\int_{0}^{t} i_C(\tau)d\tau + v_C(0)vC​(t)=C1​∫0t​iC​(τ)dτ+vC​(0)

      Inductor

      vL(t)=LdiL(t)dtv_L(t) = L \frac{di_L(t)}{dt}vL​(t)=LdtdiL​(t)​

      iL(t)=1L∫0tvL(τ)dτ+iL(0)i_L(t) = \frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{t} v_L(\tau)d\tau + i_L(0)iL​(t)=L1​∫0t​vL​(τ)dτ+iL​(0)

      Step 1: Time Domain Circuit to s-Domain Circuit

      Transformation Process 

        graph TD
    A[Time Domain Circuit for t \geq 0] --> B[Identify all components]
    B --> C[Transform Resistors: R → R]
    B --> D[Transform Capacitors: C → 1/sC]
    B --> E[Transform Inductors: L → sL]
    B --> F[Transform Sources: v_s_t → V_s_s]
    
    C --> G[Draw s-Domain Circuit]
    D --> G
    E --> G
    F --> G
    
    G --> H[Note: Initial conditions<br/>NOT included yet]
    
    style A fill:#ffebee
    style G fill:#e8f5e9
    style H fill:#fff3e0

      Detailed Transformation Rules

      Rule 1: Resistor Transformation

      Time Domain: Resistor with value RRR ohms

      s-Domain: Same resistor with value RRR ohms

      ZR(s)=RZ_R(s) = RZR​(s)=R

      Rule 2: Capacitor Transformation

      Time Domain: Capacitor with value CCC farads

      s-Domain: Impedance 1sC\frac{1}{sC}sC1​

      ZC(s)=1sCZ_C(s) = \frac{1}{sC}ZC​(s)=sC1​

      Circuit Representation (without initial conditions): Just the impedance 1sC\frac{1}{sC}sC1​

      Circuit Representation (with initial conditions, added later):

      • Impedance 1sC\frac{1}{sC}sC1​ in series with voltage source vC(0)s\frac{v_C(0)}{s}svC​(0)​

      Rule 3: Inductor Transformation

      Time Domain: Inductor with value LLL henries

      s-Domain: Impedance sLsLsL

      ZL(s)=sLZ_L(s) = sLZL​(s)=sL

      Circuit Representation (without initial conditions): Just the impedance sLsLsL

      Circuit Representation (with initial conditions, added later):

      • Option A (for KVL/Mesh): Impedance sLsLsL in series with voltage source LiL(0)Li_L(0)LiL​(0)
      • Option B (for KCL/Node): Impedance sLsLsL in parallel with current source iL(0)s\frac{i_L(0)}{s}siL​(0)​

      Rule 4: Voltage Source Transformation

      Time Domain: vs(t)v_s(t)vs​(t)

      s-Domain: Vs(s)=L{vs(t)}V_s(s) = \mathcal{L}\{v_s(t)\}Vs​(s)=L{vs​(t)}

      Common transforms:

      • Step function: V0u(t)→V0sV_0 u(t) \rightarrow \frac{V_0}{s}V0​u(t)→sV0​​
      • Exponential: V0e−atu(t)→V0s+aV_0 e^{-at}u(t) \rightarrow \frac{V_0}{s+a}V0​e−atu(t)→s+aV0​​
      • Sine: V0sin⁡(ωt)u(t)→V0ωs2+ω2V_0 \sin(\omega t)u(t) \rightarrow \frac{V_0\omega}{s^2+\omega^2}V0​sin(ωt)u(t)→s2+ω2V0​ω​
      • Cosine: V0cos⁡(ωt)u(t)→V0ss2+ω2V_0 \cos(\omega t)u(t) \rightarrow \frac{V_0 s}{s^2+\omega^2}V0​cos(ωt)u(t)→s2+ω2V0​s​

      Rule 5: Current Source Transformation

      Time Domain: is(t)i_s(t)is​(t)

      s-Domain: Is(s)=L{is(t)}I_s(s) = \mathcal{L}\{i_s(t)\}Is​(s)=L{is​(t)}

      (Same transform pairs as voltage sources)

      Example: Series RLC Circuit Transformation

      Time Domain Circuit:

      v_s(t) ---[ R ]---[ L ]---[ C ]--- ground

      s-Domain Circuit (without initial conditions):

      V_s(s) ---[ R ]---[ sL ]---[ 1/sC ]--- ground

      s-Domain Circuit (with initial conditions added later):

      V_s(s) ---[ R ]---[ sL ]---[+]---[ 1/sC ]---[+]--- ground
                          [Li_L(0)]      [v_C(0)/s]

      Where [+] indicates voltage source polarity.

      Step 2: Apply KVL/KCL to s-Domain Circuit

      Using Kirchhoff’s Laws in s-Domain 

        graph TD
    A[s-Domain Circuit] --> B{What are you solving for?}
    B -->|Voltage or<br/>Series Circuit| C[Use KVL]
    B -->|Current or<br/>Parallel Circuit| D[Use KCL]
    
    C --> E[Sum voltages around loop = 0]
    D --> F[Sum currents at node = 0]
    
    E --> G[s-Domain Algebraic Equation]
    F --> G
    
    style G fill:#e8f5e9

      KVL in s-Domain (Mesh/Loop Analysis)

      Kirchhoff’s Voltage Law: Sum of voltages around any closed loop equals zero.

      ∑Vsources(s)−∑Vdrops(s)=0\sum V_{sources}(s) - \sum V_{drops}(s) = 0∑Vsources​(s)−∑Vdrops​(s)=0

      Voltage drops across impedances:

      Vdrop(s)=I(s)⋅Z(s)V_{drop}(s) = I(s) \cdot Z(s)Vdrop​(s)=I(s)⋅Z(s)

      General KVL Equation:

      Vs(s)=I(s)⋅Z1(s)+I(s)⋅Z2(s)+⋯+I(s)⋅Zn(s)+Vinitial(s)V_s(s) = I(s) \cdot Z_1(s) + I(s) \cdot Z_2(s) + \cdots + I(s) \cdot Z_n(s) + V_{initial}(s)Vs​(s)=I(s)⋅Z1​(s)+I(s)⋅Z2​(s)+⋯+I(s)⋅Zn​(s)+Vinitial​(s)

      Where Vinitial(s)V_{initial}(s)Vinitial​(s) represents initial condition voltage sources (when added).

      KCL in s-Domain (Node Analysis)

      Kirchhoff’s Current Law: Sum of currents entering a node equals sum of currents leaving.

      ∑Ientering(s)=∑Ileaving(s)\sum I_{entering}(s) = \sum I_{leaving}(s)∑Ientering​(s)=∑Ileaving​(s)

      Current through impedance:

      I(s)=V(s)Z(s)I(s) = \frac{V(s)}{Z(s)}I(s)=Z(s)V(s)​

      General KCL Equation at a node:

      Is(s)+Iinitial(s)=Vnode(s)Z1(s)+Vnode(s)Z2(s)+⋯I_s(s) + I_{initial}(s) = \frac{V_{node}(s)}{Z_1(s)} + \frac{V_{node}(s)}{Z_2(s)} + \cdotsIs​(s)+Iinitial​(s)=Z1​(s)Vnode​(s)​+Z2​(s)Vnode​(s)​+⋯

      Where Iinitial(s)I_{initial}(s)Iinitial​(s) represents initial condition current sources (when added).

      Example: Series RLC Circuit - KVL Application

      s-Domain Circuit:

      V_s(s) ---[ R ]---[ sL ]---[ 1/sC ]--- ground
              Current I(s) flows clockwise

      Apply KVL (going clockwise):

      Vs(s)−VR(s)−VL(s)−VC(s)=0V_s(s) - V_R(s) - V_L(s) - V_C(s) = 0Vs​(s)−VR​(s)−VL​(s)−VC​(s)=0

      Substitute Ohm’s Law in s-Domain:

      Vs(s)−I(s)⋅R−I(s)⋅sL−I(s)⋅1sC=0V_s(s) - I(s) \cdot R - I(s) \cdot sL - I(s) \cdot \frac{1}{sC} = 0Vs​(s)−I(s)⋅R−I(s)⋅sL−I(s)⋅sC1​=0

      Algebraic equation in s:

      Vs(s)=I(s)[R+sL+1sC]V_s(s) = I(s) \left[ R + sL + \frac{1}{sC} \right]Vs​(s)=I(s)[R+sL+sC1​]

      This is an algebraic equation, NOT a differential equation.

      Example: Parallel RLC Circuit - KCL Application

      s-Domain Circuit:

             I_s(s)
         |
    +----+----+----+
    |    |    |    |
    R   sL  1/sC  ground

      Apply KCL at top node (voltage V(s) across all elements):

      Is(s)=IR(s)+IL(s)+IC(s)I_s(s) = I_R(s) + I_L(s) + I_C(s)Is​(s)=IR​(s)+IL​(s)+IC​(s)

      Substitute:

      Is(s)=V(s)R+V(s)sL+V(s)⋅sCI_s(s) = \frac{V(s)}{R} + \frac{V(s)}{sL} + V(s) \cdot sCIs​(s)=RV(s)​+sLV(s)​+V(s)⋅sC

      Algebraic equation in s:

      Is(s)=V(s)[1R+1sL+sC]I_s(s) = V(s) \left[ \frac{1}{R} + \frac{1}{sL} + sC \right]Is​(s)=V(s)[R1​+sL1​+sC]

      Step 3: Derive Differential Equations from s-Domain

      IMPORTANT CLARIFICATION

      When you follow PATH A (Time → s-Domain → KVL/KCL), you get an algebraic equation in sss, not a differential equation.

      However, you may be asked to “find the differential equation” which means: What time-domain differential equation corresponds to this s-domain equation?

      Converting s-Domain Equation to Differential Equation

      This is the INVERSE process, used to understand what differential equation you would have gotten if you had used PATH B.

        graph LR
    A[s-Domain Algebraic Equation] --> B[Apply Inverse Correspondence]
    B --> C[Time-Domain Differential Equation]
    
    style A fill:#e8f5e9
    style C fill:#ffe0b2

      Inverse Laplace Correspondence Rules

      These rules work backwards from the Laplace transform properties:

      s-Domain TermTime-Domain Equivalent
      V(s)V(s)V(s) or I(s)I(s)I(s)v(t)v(t)v(t) or i(t)i(t)i(t)
      s⋅V(s)s \cdot V(s)s⋅V(s)dv(t)dt\frac{dv(t)}{dt}dtdv(t)​ (plus initial condition)
      s2⋅V(s)s^2 \cdot V(s)s2⋅V(s)d2v(t)dt2\frac{d^2v(t)}{dt^2}dt2d2v(t)​ (plus initial conditions)
      V(s)s\frac{V(s)}{s}sV(s)​∫0tv(τ)dτ\int_0^t v(\tau)d\tau∫0t​v(τ)dτ
      Vs(s)V_s(s)Vs​(s)vs(t)v_s(t)vs​(t)
      Constant CCCConstant CCC

      Detailed Correspondence Rules

      Rule 1: Basic Substitution

      V(s)→v(t)V(s) \rightarrow v(t)V(s)→v(t)

      I(s)→i(t)I(s) \rightarrow i(t)I(s)→i(t)

      Rule 2: Multiplication by sss (First Derivative)

      s⋅V(s)→dv(t)dt+v(0+)s \cdot V(s) \rightarrow \frac{dv(t)}{dt} + v(0^+)s⋅V(s)→dtdv(t)​+v(0+)

      However: If initial conditions are already incorporated as sources in the s-domain circuit, then:

      s⋅V(s)→dv(t)dts \cdot V(s) \rightarrow \frac{dv(t)}{dt}s⋅V(s)→dtdv(t)​

      And the initial condition term appears separately.

      Rule 3: Multiplication by s2s^2s2 (Second Derivative)

      s2⋅V(s)→d2v(t)dt2+s⋅v(0+)+dv(0+)dts^2 \cdot V(s) \rightarrow \frac{d^2v(t)}{dt^2} + s \cdot v(0^+) + \frac{dv(0^+)}{dt}s2⋅V(s)→dt2d2v(t)​+s⋅v(0+)+dtdv(0+)​

      With initial conditions incorporated:

      s2⋅V(s)→d2v(t)dt2s^2 \cdot V(s) \rightarrow \frac{d^2v(t)}{dt^2}s2⋅V(s)→dt2d2v(t)​

      Rule 4: Division by sss (Integration)

      V(s)s→∫0tv(τ)dτ\frac{V(s)}{s} \rightarrow \int_0^t v(\tau)d\tausV(s)​→∫0t​v(τ)dτ

      Example: Converting s-Domain to Differential Equation

      Given s-Domain Equation (from Series RLC):

      Vs(s)=I(s)[R+sL+1sC]V_s(s) = I(s) \left[ R + sL + \frac{1}{sC} \right]Vs​(s)=I(s)[R+sL+sC1​]

      Step 1: Expand

      Vs(s)=R⋅I(s)+sL⋅I(s)+I(s)sCV_s(s) = R \cdot I(s) + sL \cdot I(s) + \frac{I(s)}{sC}Vs​(s)=R⋅I(s)+sL⋅I(s)+sCI(s)​

      Step 2: Multiply through by sCsCsC

      sC⋅Vs(s)=sRC⋅I(s)+s2LC⋅I(s)+I(s)sC \cdot V_s(s) = sRC \cdot I(s) + s^2LC \cdot I(s) + I(s)sC⋅Vs​(s)=sRC⋅I(s)+s2LC⋅I(s)+I(s)

      Step 3: Apply inverse correspondence

      • sC⋅Vs(s)→Cdvs(t)dtsC \cdot V_s(s) \rightarrow C\frac{dv_s(t)}{dt}sC⋅Vs​(s)→Cdtdvs​(t)​
      • sRC⋅I(s)→RCdi(t)dtsRC \cdot I(s) \rightarrow RC\frac{di(t)}{dt}sRC⋅I(s)→RCdtdi(t)​
      • s2LC⋅I(s)→LCd2i(t)dt2s^2LC \cdot I(s) \rightarrow LC\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2}s2LC⋅I(s)→LCdt2d2i(t)​
      • I(s)→i(t)I(s) \rightarrow i(t)I(s)→i(t)

      Resulting Differential Equation:

      Cdvs(t)dt=RCdi(t)dt+LCd2i(t)dt2+i(t)C\frac{dv_s(t)}{dt} = RC\frac{di(t)}{dt} + LC\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2} + i(t)Cdtdvs​(t)​=RCdtdi(t)​+LCdt2d2i(t)​+i(t)

      Or rearranged:

      LCd2i(t)dt2+RCdi(t)dt+i(t)=Cdvs(t)dtLC\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2} + RC\frac{di(t)}{dt} + i(t) = C\frac{dv_s(t)}{dt}LCdt2d2i(t)​+RCdtdi(t)​+i(t)=Cdtdvs​(t)​

      This is a second-order differential equation.

      Step 4: Setup for Laplace Transform

      At this point, you have either:

      Option A: s-Domain Algebraic Equation (from PATH A)

      You already have: An equation like Vs(s)=I(s)⋅Ztotal(s)V_s(s) = I(s) \cdot Z_{total}(s)Vs​(s)=I(s)⋅Ztotal​(s)

      To solve:

      1. Add initial condition sources (if not already included)
      2. Algebraically solve for I(s)I(s)I(s) or V(s)V(s)V(s)
      3. You now have I(s)=Vs(s)Ztotal(s)I(s) = \frac{V_s(s)}{Z_{total}(s)}I(s)=Ztotal​(s)Vs​(s)​ plus initial condition terms

      Next step: Apply Inverse Laplace Transform to get i(t)i(t)i(t) or v(t)v(t)v(t)

      You would perform Inverse Laplace Transform from here.

      Option B: Time-Domain Differential Equation (from PATH B)

      You have: A differential equation like:

      LCd2i(t)dt2+RCdi(t)dt+i(t)=Cdvs(t)dtLC\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2} + RC\frac{di(t)}{dt} + i(t) = C\frac{dv_s(t)}{dt}LCdt2d2i(t)​+RCdtdi(t)​+i(t)=Cdtdvs​(t)​

      To solve:

      1. Apply Laplace Transform to both sides
      2. Use differentiation property: L{dfdt}=sF(s)−f(0)\mathcal{L}\{\frac{df}{dt}\} = sF(s) - f(0)L{dtdf​}=sF(s)−f(0)
      3. Substitute initial conditions
      4. Solve algebraically for I(s)I(s)I(s)

      You would apply Laplace Transform from here.

      Laplace Transform Properties (for PATH B)

      Differentiation Property (First Derivative)

      L{df(t)dt}=sF(s)−f(0)\mathcal{L}\left\{\frac{df(t)}{dt}\right\} = sF(s) - f(0)L{dtdf(t)​}=sF(s)−f(0)

      Second Derivative Property

      L{d2f(t)dt2}=s2F(s)−sf(0)−f′(0)\mathcal{L}\left\{\frac{d^2f(t)}{dt^2}\right\} = s^2F(s) - sf(0) - f'(0)L{dt2d2f(t)​}=s2F(s)−sf(0)−f′(0)

      Integration Property

      L{∫0tf(τ)dτ}=F(s)s\mathcal{L}\left\{\int_0^t f(\tau) d\tau\right\} = \frac{F(s)}{s}L{∫0t​f(τ)dτ}=sF(s)​

      Linearity Property

      L{af(t)+bg(t)}=aF(s)+bG(s)\mathcal{L}\{af(t) + bg(t)\} = aF(s) + bG(s)L{af(t)+bg(t)}=aF(s)+bG(s)

      Example: Applying Laplace Transform to Differential Equation

      Given Differential Equation:

      LCd2i(t)dt2+RCdi(t)dt+i(t)=vs(t)LC\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2} + RC\frac{di(t)}{dt} + i(t) = v_s(t)LCdt2d2i(t)​+RCdtdi(t)​+i(t)=vs​(t)

      With initial conditions: i(0)=I0i(0) = I_0i(0)=I0​, di(0)dt=I0′\frac{di(0)}{dt} = I_0'dtdi(0)​=I0′​

      Step 1: Apply Laplace Transform to each term

      Left side:

      • L{LCd2i(t)dt2}=LC[s2I(s)−si(0)−i′(0)]=LC[s2I(s)−sI0−I0′]\mathcal{L}\{LC\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2}\} = LC[s^2I(s) - si(0) - i'(0)] = LC[s^2I(s) - sI_0 - I_0']L{LCdt2d2i(t)​}=LC[s2I(s)−si(0)−i′(0)]=LC[s2I(s)−sI0​−I0′​]
      • L{RCdi(t)dt}=RC[sI(s)−i(0)]=RC[sI(s)−I0]\mathcal{L}\{RC\frac{di(t)}{dt}\} = RC[sI(s) - i(0)] = RC[sI(s) - I_0]L{RCdtdi(t)​}=RC[sI(s)−i(0)]=RC[sI(s)−I0​]
      • L{i(t)}=I(s)\mathcal{L}\{i(t)\} = I(s)L{i(t)}=I(s)

      Right side:

      • L{vs(t)}=Vs(s)\mathcal{L}\{v_s(t)\} = V_s(s)L{vs​(t)}=Vs​(s)

      Step 2: Substitute into equation

      LC[s2I(s)−sI0−I0′]+RC[sI(s)−I0]+I(s)=Vs(s)LC[s^2I(s) - sI_0 - I_0'] + RC[sI(s) - I_0] + I(s) = V_s(s)LC[s2I(s)−sI0​−I0′​]+RC[sI(s)−I0​]+I(s)=Vs​(s)

      Step 3: Expand and collect terms

      LCs2I(s)−LCsI0−LCI0′+RCsI(s)−RCI0+I(s)=Vs(s)LCs^2I(s) - LCsI_0 - LCI_0' + RCsI(s) - RCI_0 + I(s) = V_s(s)LCs2I(s)−LCsI0​−LCI0′​+RCsI(s)−RCI0​+I(s)=Vs​(s)I(s)[LCs2+RCs+1]=Vs(s)+LCsI0+LCI0′+RCI0I(s)[LCs^2 + RCs + 1] = V_s(s) + LCsI_0 + LCI_0' + RCI_0I(s)[LCs2+RCs+1]=Vs​(s)+LCsI0​+LCI0′​+RCI0​

      Step 4: Solve for I(s)

      I(s)=Vs(s)+LCsI0+LCI0′+RCI0LCs2+RCs+1I(s) = \frac{V_s(s) + LCsI_0 + LCI_0' + RCI_0}{LCs^2 + RCs + 1}I(s)=LCs2+RCs+1Vs​(s)+LCsI0​+LCI0′​+RCI0​​

      You would now apply Inverse Laplace Transform to get i(t).

      Alternative Path: Differential Equation First

      When to Use This Path

      Use PATH B when:

      • The problem explicitly asks for the differential equation first
      • You’re more comfortable with time-domain analysis
      • The circuit is simple enough to analyze in time domain

      Complete PATH B Process 

        graph TD
    A[Time Domain Circuit] --> B[Apply KVL or KCL in Time Domain]
    B --> C[Use component equations:<br/>v=Ri, v=L di/dt, i=C dv/dt]
    C --> D[Substitute to get one variable]
    D --> E[Differential Equation in t]
    E --> F[Apply Laplace Transform]
    F --> G[Use differentiation property]
    G --> H[Substitute initial conditions]
    H --> I[Algebraic equation in s]
    I --> J[Solve for V_s or I_s]
    J --> K[Apply Inverse Laplace Transform]
    K --> L[Time Domain Solution]
    
    style E fill:#ffe0b2
    style F fill:#fff9c4
    style L fill:#c8e6c9

      Detailed Steps for PATH B

      Step 1: Apply KVL or KCL in Time Domain

      For Series Circuit (KVL):

      vs(t)=vR(t)+vL(t)+vC(t)v_s(t) = v_R(t) + v_L(t) + v_C(t)vs​(t)=vR​(t)+vL​(t)+vC​(t)

      For Parallel Circuit (KCL):

      is(t)=iR(t)+iL(t)+iC(t)i_s(t) = i_R(t) + i_L(t) + i_C(t)is​(t)=iR​(t)+iL​(t)+iC​(t)

      Step 2: Substitute Component Equations

      For Series RLC finding current i(t):

      From KVL:

      vs(t)=vR(t)+vL(t)+vC(t)v_s(t) = v_R(t) + v_L(t) + v_C(t)vs​(t)=vR​(t)+vL​(t)+vC​(t)

      Substitute:

      • vR(t)=Ri(t)v_R(t) = Ri(t)vR​(t)=Ri(t)
      • vL(t)=Ldi(t)dtv_L(t) = L\frac{di(t)}{dt}vL​(t)=Ldtdi(t)​
      • vC(t)=1C∫0ti(τ)dτ+vC(0)v_C(t) = \frac{1}{C}\int_0^t i(\tau)d\tau + v_C(0)vC​(t)=C1​∫0t​i(τ)dτ+vC​(0)

      Result:

      vs(t)=Ri(t)+Ldi(t)dt+1C∫0ti(τ)dτ+vC(0)v_s(t) = Ri(t) + L\frac{di(t)}{dt} + \frac{1}{C}\int_0^t i(\tau)d\tau + v_C(0)vs​(t)=Ri(t)+Ldtdi(t)​+C1​∫0t​i(τ)dτ+vC​(0)

      Step 3: Eliminate Integrals/Derivatives

      Differentiate to eliminate integral:

      dvs(t)dt=Rdi(t)dt+Ld2i(t)dt2+i(t)C\frac{dv_s(t)}{dt} = R\frac{di(t)}{dt} + L\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2} + \frac{i(t)}{C}dtdvs​(t)​=Rdtdi(t)​+Ldt2d2i(t)​+Ci(t)​

      Rearrange:

      Ld2i(t)dt2+Rdi(t)dt+i(t)C=dvs(t)dtL\frac{d^2i(t)}{dt^2} + R\frac{di(t)}{dt} + \frac{i(t)}{C} = \frac{dv_s(t)}{dt}Ldt2d2i(t)​+Rdtdi(t)​+Ci(t)​=dtdvs​(t)​

      This is your differential equation.

      Step 4: Apply Laplace Transform

      (Same process as shown in Step 4 above)

      Working Backwards: Inverse Operations

      Understanding the Reverse Process

      Sometimes you need to work backwards through the steps:

        graph LR
    A[Time Domain v_t] <--> B[Laplace Transform]
    B <--> C[s-Domain V_s]
    C <--> D[s-Domain Circuit]
    D <--> E[Time Domain Circuit]
    
    style A fill:#ffebee
    style C fill:#e8f5e9
    style E fill:#ffebee

      Reverse Operation 1: s-Domain to Time Domain Circuit

      Going Forward: Time circuit → s-Domain circuit (replace R, L, C with impedances)

      Going Backward: s-Domain circuit → Time circuit

      Reverse Transformation Table

      s-Domain ElementTime Domain Element
      Resistor RRRResistor RRR
      Impedance 1sC\frac{1}{sC}sC1​Capacitor CCC
      Impedance sLsLsLInductor LLL
      Voltage source vC(0)s\frac{v_C(0)}{s}svC​(0)​Initial condition vC(0)v_C(0)vC​(0) on capacitor
      Voltage source LiL(0)Li_L(0)LiL​(0)Initial condition iL(0)i_L(0)iL​(0) on inductor
      Vs(s)V_s(s)Vs​(s)vs(t)=L−1{Vs(s)}v_s(t) = \mathcal{L}^{-1}\{V_s(s)\}vs​(t)=L−1{Vs​(s)}

      Process:

      1. Identify each impedance element
      2. Convert impedances back to time-domain components
      3. Extract initial conditions from voltage/current sources
      4. Inverse transform any source functions

      Reverse Operation 2: s-Domain Equation to Differential Equation

      Going Forward: Differential equation → Apply Laplace → s-Domain equation

      Going Backward: s-Domain equation → Identify correspondences → Differential equation

      Process (detailed in Step 3 above):

      1. Identify all terms involving sss
      2. Apply inverse correspondence:
        • snV(s)→dnv(t)dtns^n V(s) \rightarrow \frac{d^n v(t)}{dt^n}snV(s)→dtndnv(t)​
        • V(s)s→∫v(t)dt\frac{V(s)}{s} \rightarrow \int v(t)dtsV(s)​→∫v(t)dt
      3. Substitute back to get differential equation

      Reverse Operation 3: KVL/KCL Back to Circuit

      Going Forward: Circuit → Apply KVL/KCL → Equation

      Going Backward: Equation → Identify topology → Circuit

      Key identifiers:

      • If equation has sum of voltages = source: Series circuit (KVL)
      • If equation has sum of currents = source: Parallel circuit (KCL)
      • Terms added together → Elements in series (for KVL) or parallel (for KCL)

      Example: Given: Vs(s)=I(s)[R+sL+1sC]V_s(s) = I(s)[R + sL + \frac{1}{sC}]Vs​(s)=I(s)[R+sL+sC1​]

      This indicates:

      • Series circuit (sum of impedances)
      • Contains R, L, and C in series
      • Voltage source Vs(s)V_s(s)Vs​(s)
      • Current I(s)I(s)I(s) flows through all elements

      Reverse Operation 4: Differential Equation to KVL/KCL

      Going Forward: KVL/KCL → Substitute components → Differential equation

      Going Backward: Differential equation → Identify terms → Reconstruct KVL/KCL

      Identification rules:

      • Terms with d2dt2\frac{d^2}{dt^2}dt2d2​ → Inductor (if solving for current) or Capacitor (if solving for voltage)
      • Terms with ddt\frac{d}{dt}dtd​ → Inductor (voltage) or Capacitor (current) or Resistor derivative
      • Terms without derivatives → Resistor or result of integration
      • RHS (right-hand side) → Source function

      Complete Worked Examples

      Example 1: Series RC Circuit (PATH A - Standard Exam Format)

      Part 1: Given Time Domain Circuit

      Circuit:

      v_s(t) = 10u(t) V ---[R = 100Ω]---[C = 10μF]--- ground

      Find: Voltage across capacitor, vC(t)v_C(t)vC​(t)

      Part 2: Convert to s-Domain

      Transform components:

      • Voltage source: vs(t)=10u(t)→Vs(s)=10sv_s(t) = 10u(t) \rightarrow V_s(s) = \frac{10}{s}vs​(t)=10u(t)→Vs​(s)=s10​
      • Resistor: R=100Ω→R=100ΩR = 100Ω \rightarrow R = 100ΩR=100Ω→R=100Ω
      • Capacitor: C=10μF→ZC=1sC=1s⋅10×10−6=10610s=105sC = 10μF \rightarrow Z_C = \frac{1}{sC} = \frac{1}{s \cdot 10 \times 10^{-6}} = \frac{10^6}{10s} = \frac{10^5}{s}C=10μF→ZC​=sC1​=s⋅10×10−61​=10s106​=s105​

      s-Domain circuit (without initial conditions):

      V_s(s) = 10/s ---[100]---[10^5/s]--- ground

      Part 3: Apply KVL in s-Domain

      Current flows clockwise: I(s)I(s)I(s)

      KVL around loop: Vs(s)=I(s)⋅R+VC(s)V_s(s) = I(s) \cdot R + V_C(s)Vs​(s)=I(s)⋅R+VC​(s)

      Voltage across capacitor: VC(s)=I(s)⋅ZC=I(s)⋅105sV_C(s) = I(s) \cdot Z_C = I(s) \cdot \frac{10^5}{s}VC​(s)=I(s)⋅ZC​=I(s)⋅s105​

      Substitute: 10s=I(s)⋅100+I(s)⋅105s\frac{10}{s} = I(s) \cdot 100 + I(s) \cdot \frac{10^5}{s}s10​=I(s)⋅100+I(s)⋅s105​

      10s=I(s)[100+105s]\frac{10}{s} = I(s) \left[100 + \frac{10^5}{s}\right]s10​=I(s)[100+s105​]

      10s=I(s)[100s+105s]\frac{10}{s} = I(s) \left[\frac{100s + 10^5}{s}\right]s10​=I(s)[s100s+105​]

      Solve for I(s): I(s)=10s⋅s100s+105=10100s+105I(s) = \frac{10}{s} \cdot \frac{s}{100s + 10^5} = \frac{10}{100s + 10^5}I(s)=s10​⋅100s+105s​=100s+10510​

      Simplify: I(s)=10100(s+1000)=0.1s+1000I(s) = \frac{10}{100(s + 1000)} = \frac{0.1}{s + 1000}I(s)=100(s+1000)10​=s+10000.1​

      Now find V_C(s): VC(s)=I(s)⋅105s=0.1s+1000⋅105sV_C(s) = I(s) \cdot \frac{10^5}{s} = \frac{0.1}{s + 1000} \cdot \frac{10^5}{s}VC​(s)=I(s)⋅s105​=s+10000.1​⋅s105​

      VC(s)=104s(s+1000)V_C(s) = \frac{10^4}{s(s + 1000)}VC​(s)=s(s+1000)104​

      Part 4: Initial Conditions Given Later

      Problem states: Initially, capacitor is uncharged: vC(0)=0v_C(0) = 0vC​(0)=0

      Since vC(0)=0v_C(0) = 0vC​(0)=0, no initial condition source is added. Our equation is complete.

      Part 5: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform

      We have: VC(s)=104s(s+1000)V_C(s) = \frac{10^4}{s(s + 1000)}VC​(s)=s(s+1000)104​

      At this point, you would apply Inverse Laplace Transform using partial fraction expansion.

      Example 2: Series RL Circuit with Initial Condition (PATH A)

      Part 1: Given Time Domain Circuit

      Circuit:

      v_s(t) = 5e^{-2t}u(t) V ---[R = 10Ω]---[L = 0.5H]--- ground

      Find: Current i(t)i(t)i(t)

      Part 2: Convert to s-Domain

      Transform components:

      • Voltage source: vs(t)=5e−2tu(t)→Vs(s)=5s+2v_s(t) = 5e^{-2t}u(t) \rightarrow V_s(s) = \frac{5}{s+2}vs​(t)=5e−2tu(t)→Vs​(s)=s+25​
      • Resistor: R=10ΩR = 10ΩR=10Ω
      • Inductor: L=0.5H→ZL=sL=0.5sL = 0.5H \rightarrow Z_L = sL = 0.5sL=0.5H→ZL​=sL=0.5s

      s-Domain circuit (without initial conditions):

      V_s(s) = 5/(s+2) ---[10]---[0.5s]--- ground

      Part 3: Apply KVL in s-Domain

      KVL around loop: Vs(s)=I(s)⋅R+I(s)⋅ZLV_s(s) = I(s) \cdot R + I(s) \cdot Z_LVs​(s)=I(s)⋅R+I(s)⋅ZL​

      5s+2=I(s)⋅10+I(s)⋅0.5s\frac{5}{s+2} = I(s) \cdot 10 + I(s) \cdot 0.5ss+25​=I(s)⋅10+I(s)⋅0.5s

      5s+2=I(s)[10+0.5s]\frac{5}{s+2} = I(s)[10 + 0.5s]s+25​=I(s)[10+0.5s]

      Solve for I(s): I(s)=5(s+2)(10+0.5s)=5(s+2)⋅0.5(20+s)I(s) = \frac{5}{(s+2)(10 + 0.5s)} = \frac{5}{(s+2) \cdot 0.5(20 + s)}I(s)=(s+2)(10+0.5s)5​=(s+2)⋅0.5(20+s)5​

      I(s)=10(s+2)(s+20)I(s) = \frac{10}{(s+2)(s+20)}I(s)=(s+2)(s+20)10​

      Part 4: Initial Conditions Given

      Problem now states: iL(0)=2Ai_L(0) = 2AiL​(0)=2A

      Add initial condition voltage source LiL(0)=0.5×2=1VLi_L(0) = 0.5 \times 2 = 1VLiL​(0)=0.5×2=1V in series with inductor.

      Updated s-Domain circuit:

      V_s(s) = 5/(s+2) ---[10]---[0.5s]---[+]--- ground
                                  [1V source]

      The voltage source opposes the applied voltage (it represents back-EMF from initial current).

      Updated KVL: Vs(s)=I(s)⋅R+I(s)⋅ZL+LiL(0)V_s(s) = I(s) \cdot R + I(s) \cdot Z_L + Li_L(0)Vs​(s)=I(s)⋅R+I(s)⋅ZL​+LiL​(0)

      5s+2=I(s)[10+0.5s]+1\frac{5}{s+2} = I(s)[10 + 0.5s] + 1s+25​=I(s)[10+0.5s]+1

      5s+2−1=I(s)[10+0.5s]\frac{5}{s+2} - 1 = I(s)[10 + 0.5s]s+25​−1=I(s)[10+0.5s]

      5−(s+2)s+2=I(s)[10+0.5s]\frac{5 - (s+2)}{s+2} = I(s)[10 + 0.5s]s+25−(s+2)​=I(s)[10+0.5s]

      3−ss+2=I(s)[10+0.5s]\frac{3 - s}{s+2} = I(s)[10 + 0.5s]s+23−s​=I(s)[10+0.5s]

      Solve for I(s): I(s)=3−s(s+2)(10+0.5s)=3−s0.5(s+2)(s+20)I(s) = \frac{3-s}{(s+2)(10+0.5s)} = \frac{3-s}{0.5(s+2)(s+20)}I(s)=(s+2)(10+0.5s)3−s​=0.5(s+2)(s+20)3−s​

      I(s)=2(3−s)(s+2)(s+20)I(s) = \frac{2(3-s)}{(s+2)(s+20)}I(s)=(s+2)(s+20)2(3−s)​

      Part 5: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform

      We have: I(s)=2(3−s)(s+2)(s+20)=6−2s(s+2)(s+20)I(s) = \frac{2(3-s)}{(s+2)(s+20)} = \frac{6-2s}{(s+2)(s+20)}I(s)=(s+2)(s+20)2(3−s)​=(s+2)(s+20)6−2s​

      At this point, you would apply Inverse Laplace Transform.

      Example 3: Deriving Differential Equation from s-Domain (PATH A with Step 3)

      Given: s-Domain Equation

      From Example 1, we had: Vs(s)=I(s)[R+ZC]V_s(s) = I(s)[R + Z_C]Vs​(s)=I(s)[R+ZC​]

      For RC circuit: Vs(s)=I(s)[R+1sC]V_s(s) = I(s)\left[R + \frac{1}{sC}\right]Vs​(s)=I(s)[R+sC1​]

      Find: Corresponding Differential Equation

      Step 1: Express in standard form Vs(s)=RI(s)+I(s)sCV_s(s) = RI(s) + \frac{I(s)}{sC}Vs​(s)=RI(s)+sCI(s)​

      Step 2: Relate current to voltage

      For a capacitor: I(s)=sC⋅VC(s)I(s) = sC \cdot V_C(s)I(s)=sC⋅VC​(s)

      Substitute: Vs(s)=R⋅sC⋅VC(s)+sC⋅VC(s)sCV_s(s) = R \cdot sC \cdot V_C(s) + \frac{sC \cdot V_C(s)}{sC}Vs​(s)=R⋅sC⋅VC​(s)+sCsC⋅VC​(s)​

      Vs(s)=RsC⋅VC(s)+VC(s)V_s(s) = RsC \cdot V_C(s) + V_C(s)Vs​(s)=RsC⋅VC​(s)+VC​(s)

      Vs(s)=VC(s)[1+RsC]V_s(s) = V_C(s)[1 + RsC]Vs​(s)=VC​(s)[1+RsC]

      Step 3: Apply inverse correspondence

      • Vs(s)→vs(t)V_s(s) \rightarrow v_s(t)Vs​(s)→vs​(t)
      • VC(s)→vC(t)V_C(s) \rightarrow v_C(t)VC​(s)→vC​(t)
      • sC⋅VC(s)→CdvC(t)dtsC \cdot V_C(s) \rightarrow C\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}sC⋅VC​(s)→CdtdvC​(t)​

      From the equation: Vs(s)=VC(s)+RC⋅s⋅VC(s)V_s(s) = V_C(s) + RC \cdot s \cdot V_C(s)Vs​(s)=VC​(s)+RC⋅s⋅VC​(s)

      Time domain: vs(t)=vC(t)+RCdvC(t)dtv_s(t) = v_C(t) + RC\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}vs​(t)=vC​(t)+RCdtdvC​(t)​

      This is the first-order differential equation.

      Rearranged: RCdvC(t)dt+vC(t)=vs(t)RC\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt} + v_C(t) = v_s(t)RCdtdvC​(t)​+vC​(t)=vs​(t)

      Or: dvC(t)dt+1RCvC(t)=vs(t)RC\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt} + \frac{1}{RC}v_C(t) = \frac{v_s(t)}{RC}dtdvC​(t)​+RC1​vC​(t)=RCvs​(t)​

      Example 4: Complete PATH B Process (Differential Equation First)

      Part 1: Given Time Domain Circuit

      Circuit:

      v_s(t) = 10u(t) V ---[R = 2Ω]---[L = 1H]--- ground

      Find: Current i(t)i(t)i(t), given iL(0)=0i_L(0) = 0iL​(0)=0

      Part 2: Apply KVL in Time Domain

      KVL around loop: vs(t)=vR(t)+vL(t)v_s(t) = v_R(t) + v_L(t)vs​(t)=vR​(t)+vL​(t)

      Part 3: Substitute Component Equations

      • vR(t)=R⋅i(t)=2i(t)v_R(t) = R \cdot i(t) = 2i(t)vR​(t)=R⋅i(t)=2i(t)
      • vL(t)=Ldi(t)dt=1⋅di(t)dt=di(t)dtv_L(t) = L\frac{di(t)}{dt} = 1 \cdot \frac{di(t)}{dt} = \frac{di(t)}{dt}vL​(t)=Ldtdi(t)​=1⋅dtdi(t)​=dtdi(t)​

      Substitute: vs(t)=2i(t)+di(t)dtv_s(t) = 2i(t) + \frac{di(t)}{dt}vs​(t)=2i(t)+dtdi(t)​

      Given: vs(t)=10u(t)v_s(t) = 10u(t)vs​(t)=10u(t)

      Differential equation: di(t)dt+2i(t)=10u(t)\frac{di(t)}{dt} + 2i(t) = 10u(t)dtdi(t)​+2i(t)=10u(t)

      For t>0t > 0t>0 (where u(t)=1u(t) = 1u(t)=1): di(t)dt+2i(t)=10\frac{di(t)}{dt} + 2i(t) = 10dtdi(t)​+2i(t)=10

      Part 4: Apply Laplace Transform

      Transform both sides: L{di(t)dt}+2L{i(t)}=L{10}\mathcal{L}\left\{\frac{di(t)}{dt}\right\} + 2\mathcal{L}\{i(t)\} = \mathcal{L}\{10\}L{dtdi(t)​}+2L{i(t)}=L{10}

      Use differentiation property: sI(s)−i(0)+2I(s)=10ssI(s) - i(0) + 2I(s) = \frac{10}{s}sI(s)−i(0)+2I(s)=s10​

      Given: i(0)=0i(0) = 0i(0)=0

      sI(s)+2I(s)=10ssI(s) + 2I(s) = \frac{10}{s}sI(s)+2I(s)=s10​

      I(s)[s+2]=10sI(s)[s + 2] = \frac{10}{s}I(s)[s+2]=s10​

      Solve for I(s): I(s)=10s(s+2)I(s) = \frac{10}{s(s+2)}I(s)=s(s+2)10​

      Part 5: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform

      We have: I(s)=10s(s+2)I(s) = \frac{10}{s(s+2)}I(s)=s(s+2)10​

      At this point, you would apply Inverse Laplace Transform.

      Example 5: Parallel RLC with Node Analysis (PATH A)

      Part 1: Given Time Domain Circuit

      Circuit:

               i_s(t) = 2u(t) A
              |
         +----+----+----+
         |    |    |    |
        R=5  L=2H C=0.1F
         |    |    |    |
       ground ground ground

      Find: Voltage v(t)v(t)v(t) across all elements

      Part 2: Convert to s-Domain

      Transform components:

      • Current source: is(t)=2u(t)→Is(s)=2si_s(t) = 2u(t) \rightarrow I_s(s) = \frac{2}{s}is​(t)=2u(t)→Is​(s)=s2​
      • Resistor: R=5ΩR = 5ΩR=5Ω
      • Inductor: ZL=sL=2sZ_L = sL = 2sZL​=sL=2s (use parallel form with current source for KCL)
      • Capacitor: ZC=1sC=10.1s=10sZ_C = \frac{1}{sC} = \frac{1}{0.1s} = \frac{10}{s}ZC​=sC1​=0.1s1​=s10​

      s-Domain circuit (without initial conditions):

               I_s(s) = 2/s
              |
         +----+----+----+
         |    |    |    |
        R=5  2s   10/s
         |    |    |    |
       ground

      Voltage V(s)V(s)V(s) appears across all elements.

      Part 3: Apply KCL at Top Node

      KCL (currents leaving node): Is(s)=IR(s)+IL(s)+IC(s)I_s(s) = I_R(s) + I_L(s) + I_C(s)Is​(s)=IR​(s)+IL​(s)+IC​(s)

      Express currents in terms of V(s):

      • IR(s)=V(s)R=V(s)5I_R(s) = \frac{V(s)}{R} = \frac{V(s)}{5}IR​(s)=RV(s)​=5V(s)​
      • IL(s)=V(s)ZL=V(s)2sI_L(s) = \frac{V(s)}{Z_L} = \frac{V(s)}{2s}IL​(s)=ZL​V(s)​=2sV(s)​
      • IC(s)=V(s)ZC=V(s)⋅s10=sV(s)10I_C(s) = \frac{V(s)}{Z_C} = V(s) \cdot \frac{s}{10} = \frac{sV(s)}{10}IC​(s)=ZC​V(s)​=V(s)⋅10s​=10sV(s)​

      Substitute: 2s=V(s)5+V(s)2s+sV(s)10\frac{2}{s} = \frac{V(s)}{5} + \frac{V(s)}{2s} + \frac{sV(s)}{10}s2​=5V(s)​+2sV(s)​+10sV(s)​

      Factor out V(s): 2s=V(s)[15+12s+s10]\frac{2}{s} = V(s)\left[\frac{1}{5} + \frac{1}{2s} + \frac{s}{10}\right]s2​=V(s)[51​+2s1​+10s​]

      Find common denominator (10s): 2s=V(s)[2s10s+510s+s210s]\frac{2}{s} = V(s)\left[\frac{2s}{10s} + \frac{5}{10s} + \frac{s^2}{10s}\right]s2​=V(s)[10s2s​+10s5​+10ss2​]

      2s=V(s)[2s+5+s210s]\frac{2}{s} = V(s)\left[\frac{2s + 5 + s^2}{10s}\right]s2​=V(s)[10s2s+5+s2​]

      2s=V(s)[s2+2s+510s]\frac{2}{s} = V(s)\left[\frac{s^2 + 2s + 5}{10s}\right]s2​=V(s)[10ss2+2s+5​]

      Solve for V(s): V(s)=2s⋅10ss2+2s+5V(s) = \frac{2}{s} \cdot \frac{10s}{s^2 + 2s + 5}V(s)=s2​⋅s2+2s+510s​

      V(s)=20s2+2s+5V(s) = \frac{20}{s^2 + 2s + 5}V(s)=s2+2s+520​

      Part 4: Initial Conditions Given

      Problem states: vC(0)=0Vv_C(0) = 0VvC​(0)=0V, iL(0)=1Ai_L(0) = 1AiL​(0)=1A

      For inductor in parallel form: Add current source iL(0)s=1s\frac{i_L(0)}{s} = \frac{1}{s}siL​(0)​=s1​ in parallel with ZLZ_LZL​

      Updated KCL: Is(s)=IR(s)+IL(s)+IC(s)+IL,initial(s)I_s(s) = I_R(s) + I_L(s) + I_C(s) + I_{L,initial}(s)Is​(s)=IR​(s)+IL​(s)+IC​(s)+IL,initial​(s)

      Where IL,initial(s)=−iL(0)s=−1sI_{L,initial}(s) = -\frac{i_L(0)}{s} = -\frac{1}{s}IL,initial​(s)=−siL​(0)​=−s1​ (negative because it flows out of the node initially)

      Actually, the correct polarity: the initial current source flows in the same direction as the inductor would naturally discharge.

      Updated equation: 2s=V(s)5+V(s)2s+sV(s)10−1s\frac{2}{s} = \frac{V(s)}{5} + \frac{V(s)}{2s} + \frac{sV(s)}{10} - \frac{1}{s}s2​=5V(s)​+2sV(s)​+10sV(s)​−s1​

      2s+1s=V(s)[15+12s+s10]\frac{2}{s} + \frac{1}{s} = V(s)\left[\frac{1}{5} + \frac{1}{2s} + \frac{s}{10}\right]s2​+s1​=V(s)[51​+2s1​+10s​]

      3s=V(s)[s2+2s+510s]\frac{3}{s} = V(s)\left[\frac{s^2 + 2s + 5}{10s}\right]s3​=V(s)[10ss2+2s+5​]

      Solve for V(s): V(s)=3s⋅10ss2+2s+5=30s2+2s+5V(s) = \frac{3}{s} \cdot \frac{10s}{s^2 + 2s + 5} = \frac{30}{s^2 + 2s + 5}V(s)=s3​⋅s2+2s+510s​=s2+2s+530​

      Part 5: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform

      We have: V(s)=30s2+2s+5V(s) = \frac{30}{s^2 + 2s + 5}V(s)=s2+2s+530​

      At this point, you would apply Inverse Laplace Transform.

      Tips and Tricks

      General Strategy

      Tip 1: Choose Your Analysis Method Based on Circuit Topology

      • Series-dominant circuit: Use KVL/Mesh analysis
      • Parallel-dominant circuit: Use KCL/Node analysis
      • Mixed circuit: Count nodes vs. loops, choose method with fewer equations

      Tip 2: Initial Condition Handling

      When initial conditions are given AFTER you’ve already set up the s-domain circuit:

      1. Don’t panic - this is common in exams
      2. Add the initial condition sources to your existing s-domain circuit
      3. Update your KVL/KCL equation with the new source terms
      4. Re-solve for the variable of interest

      Tip 3: Impedance Combination

      Combine impedances BEFORE applying KVL/KCL to simplify algebra:

      Series impedances: Ztotal=Z1+Z2+Z3+⋯Z_{total} = Z_1 + Z_2 + Z_3 + \cdotsZtotal​=Z1​+Z2​+Z3​+⋯

      Parallel impedances: 1Ztotal=1Z1+1Z2+1Z3+⋯\frac{1}{Z_{total}} = \frac{1}{Z_1} + \frac{1}{Z_2} + \frac{1}{Z_3} + \cdotsZtotal​1​=Z1​1​+Z2​1​+Z3​1​+⋯

      Or for two impedances: Ztotal=Z1Z2Z1+Z2Z_{total} = \frac{Z_1 Z_2}{Z_1 + Z_2}Ztotal​=Z1​+Z2​Z1​Z2​​

      Component Transformation Tips

      Tip 4: Capacitor Impedance Direction

      The impedance 1sC\frac{1}{sC}sC1​ becomes:

      • Large (open circuit) at low frequencies (s→0s \to 0s→0, DC)
      • Small (short circuit) at high frequencies (s→∞s \to \inftys→∞)

      Tip 5: Inductor Impedance Direction

      The impedance sLsLsL becomes:

      • Small (short circuit) at low frequencies (s→0s \to 0s→0, DC)
      • Large (open circuit) at high frequencies (s→∞s \to \inftys→∞)

      Tip 6: Initial Condition Polarity for Capacitors

      When adding the initial condition voltage source vC(0)s\frac{v_C(0)}{s}svC​(0)​:

      • If vC(0)>0v_C(0) > 0vC​(0)>0: The + terminal of the source is on the same side as the + terminal of the capacitor’s initial voltage
      • The source “helps” discharge the capacitor

      Tip 7: Initial Condition Choice for Inductors

      You have two equivalent options:

      • Series voltage source: LiL(0)Li_L(0)LiL​(0) - easier for KVL
      • Parallel current source: iL(0)s\frac{i_L(0)}{s}siL​(0)​ - easier for KCL

      Use source transformation to convert between them if needed: LiL(0) (series with sL)≡iL(0)s (parallel with sL)Li_L(0) \text{ (series with } sL) \equiv \frac{i_L(0)}{s} \text{ (parallel with } sL)LiL​(0) (series with sL)≡siL​(0)​ (parallel with sL)

      Equation Setup Tips

      Tip 8: Factor Out the Unknown

      Always factor out I(s)I(s)I(s) or V(s)V(s)V(s) as soon as possible:

      Instead of: 10s=100I(s)+105I(s)s\frac{10}{s} = 100I(s) + \frac{10^5 I(s)}{s}s10​=100I(s)+s105I(s)​

      Write: 10s=I(s)[100+105s]\frac{10}{s} = I(s)\left[100 + \frac{10^5}{s}\right]s10​=I(s)[100+s105​]

      Tip 9: Common Denominator Strategy

      When combining impedances with different sss terms:

      R+1sC=RsC+1sCR + \frac{1}{sC} = \frac{RsC + 1}{sC}R+sC1​=sCRsC+1​

      R+sL=R+sL (already simplified)R + sL = R + sL \text{ (already simplified)}R+sL=R+sL (already simplified)

      1sL+sC=1+s2LCsL\frac{1}{sL} + sC = \frac{1 + s^2LC}{sL}sL1​+sC=sL1+s2LC​

      Tip 10: Simplify Before Solving

      Look for opportunities to simplify:

      • Factor out constants
      • Cancel common terms in numerator and denominator
      • Combine like terms

      Example: I(s)=100100(s+10)=1s+10I(s) = \frac{100}{100(s+10)} = \frac{1}{s+10}I(s)=100(s+10)100​=s+101​

      Differential Equation Derivation Tips

      Tip 11: Matching Powers of s

      When deriving differential equations from s-domain:

      • s0s^0s0 (constant) → original function
      • s1s^1s1 → first derivative
      • s2s^2s2 → second derivative

      Tip 12: Clear Fractions First

      Before applying inverse correspondence, multiply through to eliminate fractions:

      Given: Vs(s)=I(s)[R+sL+1sC]V_s(s) = I(s)\left[R + sL + \frac{1}{sC}\right]Vs​(s)=I(s)[R+sL+sC1​]

      Multiply by sCsCsC: sCVs(s)=I(s)[RsC+s2LC+1]sCVs(s) = I(s)[RsC + s^2LC + 1]sCVs(s)=I(s)[RsC+s2LC+1]

      Now apply inverse correspondence more easily.

      Tip 13: Identify the Dependent Variable

      Make sure you know what variable your differential equation should be in terms of:

      • If solving for current, derive equation in terms of i(t)i(t)i(t)
      • If solving for voltage, derive equation in terms of v(t)v(t)v(t)
      • Use component relationships to substitute and eliminate other variables

      Verification Tips

      Tip 14: Dimensional Analysis

      Check units throughout:

      • [R]=Ω[R] = \Omega[R]=Ω
      • [sL]=s⋅H=Ω[sL] = s \cdot H = \Omega[sL]=s⋅H=Ω (since H=Ω⋅sH = \Omega \cdot sH=Ω⋅s)
      • [1sC]=1s⋅F=Ω[\frac{1}{sC}] = \frac{1}{s \cdot F} = \Omega[sC1​]=s⋅F1​=Ω (since F=sΩF = \frac{s}{\Omega}F=Ωs​)
      • All impedances must have units of Ohms

      Tip 15: Initial Value Check

      Use Initial Value Theorem to verify: lim⁡t→0+f(t)=lim⁡s→∞sF(s)\lim_{t \to 0^+} f(t) = \lim_{s \to \infty} sF(s)limt→0+​f(t)=lims→∞​sF(s)

      Check if your V(s)V(s)V(s) or I(s)I(s)I(s) gives the correct initial value.

      Tip 16: Final Value Check

      Use Final Value Theorem (for stable systems): lim⁡t→∞f(t)=lim⁡s→0sF(s)\lim_{t \to \infty} f(t) = \lim_{s \to 0} sF(s)limt→∞​f(t)=lims→0​sF(s)

      For DC steady state, this should match your circuit analysis at s=0s = 0s=0.

      Problem-Solving Workflow

      Tip 17: Standard Exam Approach

      1. Read entire problem - note what’s given and what’s asked
      2. Draw s-domain circuit (without initial conditions first)
      3. Choose KVL or KCL based on topology
      4. Write equation in s-domain
      5. When initial conditions are given, add them to circuit and equation
      6. Solve algebraically for V(s)V(s)V(s) or I(s)I(s)I(s)
      7. State “ready for inverse Laplace transform”

      Tip 18: Sign Convention Consistency

      • Choose current direction at the start
      • Mark it clearly on your circuit diagram
      • Stick with it throughout the problem
      • Voltage drops are positive in the direction of current (passive sign convention)

      Tip 19: Organize Your Work

      Label each step clearly:

      • “s-Domain Circuit Transformation”
      • “Apply KVL” or “Apply KCL”
      • “Add Initial Conditions”
      • “Solve for V(s)” or “Solve for I(s)”
      • “Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform”

      This makes it easier for graders and helps you catch errors.

      Advanced Tips

      Tip 20: Source Transformation in s-Domain

      You can perform source transformations in s-domain just like in time domain:

      Voltage source Vs(s)V_s(s)Vs​(s) in series with ZZZ ↔ Current source Is(s)=Vs(s)ZI_s(s) = \frac{V_s(s)}{Z}Is​(s)=ZVs​(s)​ in parallel with ZZZ

      Use this to simplify circuits before analysis.

      Tip 21: Thevenin/Norton in s-Domain

      For complex circuits, find Thevenin or Norton equivalent:

      • Vth(s)V_{th}(s)Vth​(s) = open circuit voltage
      • Zth(s)Z_{th}(s)Zth​(s) = impedance with sources zeroed
      • IN(s)=Vth(s)Zth(s)I_N(s) = \frac{V_{th}(s)}{Z_{th}(s)}IN​(s)=Zth​(s)Vth​(s)​

      Tip 22: Voltage and Current Dividers

      Use these shortcuts in s-domain:

      Voltage divider: V1(s)=Vin(s)⋅Z1Z1+Z2V_1(s) = V_{in}(s) \cdot \frac{Z_1}{Z_1 + Z_2}V1​(s)=Vin​(s)⋅Z1​+Z2​Z1​​

      Current divider: I1(s)=Iin(s)⋅Z2Z1+Z2I_1(s) = I_{in}(s) \cdot \frac{Z_2}{Z_1 + Z_2}I1​(s)=Iin​(s)⋅Z1​+Z2​Z2​​

      Tip 23: Natural Response vs Forced Response

      Your s-domain solution contains both:

      • Poles from circuit (denominator of 1Ztotal\frac{1}{Z_{total}}Ztotal​1​) → natural response
      • Poles from source (denominator of Vs(s)V_s(s)Vs​(s) or Is(s)I_s(s)Is​(s)) → forced response

      This becomes clear after inverse transformation.

      Tip 24: Quick Mental Checks

      Before inverse transforming:

      • Degree of denominator \geq degree of numerator (for proper rational function)
      • All poles should be in left half-plane for stable circuit
      • Number of poles tells you order of differential equation

      Common Pitfalls

      Transformation Errors

      Pitfall 1: Wrong Impedance Formula

      WRONG: ZC=sCZ_C = sCZC​=sC or ZC=CZ_C = CZC​=C

      CORRECT: ZC=1sCZ_C = \frac{1}{sC}ZC​=sC1​

      WRONG: ZL=LsZ_L = \frac{L}{s}ZL​=sL​ or ZL=LZ_L = LZL​=L

      CORRECT: ZL=sLZ_L = sLZL​=sL

      Pitfall 2: Forgetting the sss Variable

      When working in s-domain, ALWAYS include sss:

      WRONG: V(s)=I(s)[R+L+1C]V(s) = I(s)[R + L + \frac{1}{C}]V(s)=I(s)[R+L+C1​]

      CORRECT: V(s)=I(s)[R+sL+1sC]V(s) = I(s)[R + sL + \frac{1}{sC}]V(s)=I(s)[R+sL+sC1​]

      Pitfall 3: Initial Condition Source Form

      WRONG: Capacitor initial condition = vC(0)v_C(0)vC​(0)

      CORRECT: Capacitor initial condition = vC(0)s\frac{v_C(0)}{s}svC​(0)​

      WRONG: Inductor series voltage source = iL(0)i_L(0)iL​(0)

      CORRECT: Inductor series voltage source = LiL(0)Li_L(0)LiL​(0)

      WRONG: Inductor parallel current source = iL(0)i_L(0)iL​(0)

      CORRECT: Inductor parallel current source = iL(0)s\frac{i_L(0)}{s}siL​(0)​

      Sign and Polarity Errors

      Pitfall 4: Initial Condition Polarity

      The initial condition sources must have correct polarity:

      • Capacitor voltage source: reflects actual stored voltage polarity
      • Inductor current source: flows in direction of initial current
      • Wrong polarity gives negative of correct answer

      Pitfall 5: KVL Sign Errors

      Going around loop, be consistent:

      • Voltage rises (- to +) are positive if going that direction
      • Voltage drops (+ to -) are negative if going that direction
      • OR: Set all drops in current direction as positive (passive convention)

      Pitfall 6: KCL Direction Errors

      At a node:

      • Currents entering: one sign (usually positive)
      • Currents leaving: opposite sign (usually negative)
      • Be consistent throughout

      Algebraic Errors

      Pitfall 7: Fraction Combination

      WRONG: 1sC+R=1+RsC\frac{1}{sC} + R = \frac{1 + R}{sC}sC1​+R=sC1+R​

      CORRECT: 1sC+R=1+RsCsC\frac{1}{sC} + R = \frac{1 + RsC}{sC}sC1​+R=sC1+RsC​

      Pitfall 8: Factoring Errors

      When factoring out I(s)I(s)I(s) or V(s)V(s)V(s), check EVERY term:

      WRONG: RI(s)+sLI(s)+I(s)sC=I(s)[R+sL]RI(s) + sLI(s) + \frac{I(s)}{sC} = I(s)[R + sL]RI(s)+sLI(s)+sCI(s)​=I(s)[R+sL]

      CORRECT: RI(s)+sLI(s)+I(s)sC=I(s)[R+sL+1sC]RI(s) + sLI(s) + \frac{I(s)}{sC} = I(s)[R + sL + \frac{1}{sC}]RI(s)+sLI(s)+sCI(s)​=I(s)[R+sL+sC1​]

      Pitfall 9: Solving for Wrong Variable

      Make sure you’re solving for what’s asked:

      • Problem asks for VC(s)V_C(s)VC​(s) but you solved for I(s)I(s)I(s) - must convert
      • Use VC(s)=I(s)⋅ZCV_C(s) = I(s) \cdot Z_CVC​(s)=I(s)⋅ZC​ or similar relationships

      Conceptual Errors

      Pitfall 10: Mixing Time and s-Domain

      NEVER write v(t)v(t)v(t) in an s-domain equation or V(s)V(s)V(s) in a time-domain equation.

      WRONG: V(s)=R⋅i(t)V(s) = R \cdot i(t)V(s)=R⋅i(t)

      CORRECT: V(s)=R⋅I(s)V(s) = R \cdot I(s)V(s)=R⋅I(s) (s-domain) or v(t)=R⋅i(t)v(t) = R \cdot i(t)v(t)=R⋅i(t) (time-domain)

      Pitfall 11: Assuming Zero Initial Conditions

      Unless explicitly stated or obvious (circuit just turned on from de-energized state), NEVER assume vC(0)=0v_C(0) = 0vC​(0)=0 or iL(0)=0i_L(0) = 0iL​(0)=0.

      Wait for problem to give initial conditions or solve for them from t<0t < 0t<0 analysis.

      Pitfall 12: Wrong Differential Equation Order

      The order of the differential equation equals:

      • Number of energy storage elements (L and C) in general
      • For series/parallel RLC: second order
      • For RC or RL: first order

      If you get wrong order, check your derivation.

      Pitfall 13: Forgetting u(t) in Sources

      When transforming sources, don’t forget the unit step:

      vs(t)=10v_s(t) = 10vs​(t)=10 for t>0t > 0t>0 means vs(t)=10u(t)v_s(t) = 10u(t)vs​(t)=10u(t)

      WRONG: L{10}=10\mathcal{L}\{10\} = 10L{10}=10

      CORRECT: L{10u(t)}=10s\mathcal{L}\{10u(t)\} = \frac{10}{s}L{10u(t)}=s10​

      Pitfall 14: Incorrect Source Transformation

      When converting between series and parallel forms:

      For inductor initial condition:

      Series: sLsLsL with voltage source LiL(0)Li_L(0)LiL​(0)

      ↔ Parallel: sLsLsL with current source iL(0)s\frac{i_L(0)}{s}siL​(0)​

      The relationship: LiL(0)=(sL)⋅iL(0)sLi_L(0) = (sL) \cdot \frac{i_L(0)}{s}LiL​(0)=(sL)⋅siL​(0)​ [CHECK]

      NOT: LiL(0)=(sL)iL(0)Li_L(0) = \frac{(sL)}{i_L(0)}LiL​(0)=iL​(0)(sL)​ [X]

      Units and Scaling Errors

      Pitfall 15: Unit Conversion

      Watch for μF, mH, kΩ, etc.:

      • 10μF=10×10−6F10μF = 10 \times 10^{-6} F10μF=10×10−6F
      • 5mH=5×10−3H5mH = 5 \times 10^{-3} H5mH=5×10−3H
      • 2kΩ=2×103Ω2kΩ = 2 \times 10^3 Ω2kΩ=2×103Ω

      Pitfall 16: Dimensional Inconsistency

      All terms in an equation must have same dimensions:

      • In V(s)=I(s)Z(s)V(s) = I(s)Z(s)V(s)=I(s)Z(s): all terms must be voltage
      • In I(s)=V(s)Z(s)I(s) = \frac{V(s)}{Z(s)}I(s)=Z(s)V(s)​: all terms must be current
      • Check by dimension analysis if unsure

      Summary Flow Charts

      Complete PATH A Process 

        graph TD
    A[START: Time Domain Circuit] --> B[Transform all components to s-domain<br/>R→R, C→1/sC, L→sL, sources→transformed]
    B --> C[Draw s-domain circuit<br/>without initial conditions]
    C --> D{Series or Parallel?}
    D -->|Series| E[Apply KVL]
    D -->|Parallel| F[Apply KCL]
    E --> G[Get algebraic equation in s]
    F --> G
    G --> H{Initial conditions given?}
    H -->|No| I[Equation complete<br/>Solve for Vs or Is]
    H -->|Yes| J[Add initial condition sources<br/>to circuit and equation]
    J --> K[Update equation<br/>Solve for Vs or Is]
    I --> L[Expression for Vs or Is]
    K --> L
    L --> M[END: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform]
    
    style A fill:#ffebee
    style C fill:#fff3e0
    style G fill:#e8f5e9
    style L fill:#e1f5ff
    style M fill:#c8e6c9

      Complete PATH B Process 

        graph TD
    A[START: Time Domain Circuit] --> B[Apply KVL or KCL in time domain]
    B --> C[Substitute component equations<br/>v=Ri, v=L di/dt, i=C dv/dt]
    C --> D[Manipulate to get single variable]
    D --> E[Differential Equation in time domain]
    E --> F{Initial conditions given?}
    F -->|Yes| G[Note initial conditions<br/>ft=0, f't=0]
    F -->|No| H[Solve for initial conditions<br/>from t less than 0 circuit]
    G --> I[Apply Laplace Transform]
    H --> I
    I --> J[Use differentiation property<br/>Ldf/dt = sFs - f0]
    J --> K[Substitute initial conditions]
    K --> L[Algebraic equation in s]
    L --> M[Solve for Vs or Is]
    M --> N[END: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform]
    
    style A fill:#ffebee
    style E fill:#ffe0b2
    style I fill:#fff9c4
    style L fill:#e8f5e9
    style M fill:#e1f5ff
    style N fill:#c8e6c9

      Choosing Between PATH A and PATH B 

        graph TD
    A[Circuit Analysis Problem] --> B{What does problem ask for?}
    B -->|Convert to s-domain first| C[Use PATH A<br/>Direct Transformation]
    B -->|Find differential equation| D[Use PATH B<br/>or derive from PATH A]
    B -->|Either approach works| E{What's easier?}
    
    E -->|Complex circuit| C
    E -->|Simple circuit| F[Either path fine]
    E -->|Want to understand physics| D
    E -->|Time pressure| C
    
    C --> G[Transform → KVL/KCL → Algebraic equation]
    D --> H[KVL/KCL → Diff Eq → Laplace Transform]
    F --> G
    F --> H
    
    G --> I[Solve in s-domain]
    H --> I

      Analysis Method Selection Guide

      Circuit TypeRecommended MethodWhy
      Series RLCKVL (Mesh)Elements share same current
      Parallel RLCKCL (Node)Elements share same voltage
      Ladder networkNode analysisUsually fewer nodes than loops
      Multiple sourcesMesh analysisOften fewer loops
      Want currentKVL/MeshDirectly gives current
      Want voltageKCL/NodeDirectly gives voltage
      2-3 nodesNode analysisQuick setup
      2-3 loopsMesh analysisQuick setup

      Common Circuit Transfer Functions

      CircuitConfigurationTransfer Function H(s)=Vout(s)Vin(s)H(s) = \frac{V_{out}(s)}{V_{in}(s)}H(s)=Vin​(s)Vout​(s)​
      RC Low-passSeries RC, output across C11+RCs\frac{1}{1 + RCs}1+RCs1​
      RC High-passSeries RC, output across RRCs1+RCs\frac{RCs}{1 + RCs}1+RCsRCs​
      RL Low-passSeries RL, output across RRR+sL\frac{R}{R + sL}R+sLR​
      RL High-passSeries RL, output across LsLR+sL\frac{sL}{R + sL}R+sLsL​
      Series RLCOutput across C1LCs2+RCs+1\frac{1}{LCs^2 + RCs + 1}LCs2+RCs+11​
      Parallel RLCCurrent divider to R11+R(1sL+sC)\frac{1}{1 + R(\frac{1}{sL} + sC)}1+R(sL1​+sC)1​

      Additional Worked Example: Mixed Circuit

      Example 6: Mixed Series-Parallel Circuit (Complete PATH A)

      Problem Statement

      Given the following circuit for t≥0t \geq 0t≥0:

      v_s(t) = 12u(t) V ---[R1 = 4Ω]---+---[R2 = 6Ω]--- ground
                                  |
                                  C = 0.05F
                                  |
                                ground

      Find: Voltage across capacitor vC(t)v_C(t)vC​(t)

      Given later: vC(0)=2Vv_C(0) = 2VvC​(0)=2V

      Step 1: Convert to s-Domain

      Transform components:

      • Voltage source: vs(t)=12u(t)→Vs(s)=12sv_s(t) = 12u(t) \rightarrow V_s(s) = \frac{12}{s}vs​(t)=12u(t)→Vs​(s)=s12​
      • R1=4ΩR_1 = 4ΩR1​=4Ω (unchanged)
      • R2=6ΩR_2 = 6ΩR2​=6Ω (unchanged)
      • Capacitor: C=0.05F→ZC=1sC=10.05s=20sC = 0.05F \rightarrow Z_C = \frac{1}{sC} = \frac{1}{0.05s} = \frac{20}{s}C=0.05F→ZC​=sC1​=0.05s1​=s20​

      s-Domain circuit (without initial conditions):

      V_s(s) = 12/s ---[4Ω]---+---[6Ω]--- ground
                         |
                        20/s
                         |
                       ground

      Step 2: Simplify Circuit - Combine Parallel Elements

      R2R_2R2​ and ZCZ_CZC​ are in parallel. Their equivalent impedance:

      Zparallel=R2⋅ZCR2+ZC=6⋅20s6+20sZ_{parallel} = \frac{R_2 \cdot Z_C}{R_2 + Z_C} = \frac{6 \cdot \frac{20}{s}}{6 + \frac{20}{s}}Zparallel​=R2​+ZC​R2​⋅ZC​​=6+s20​6⋅s20​​

      Zparallel=120s6s+20s=120s⋅s6s+20=1206s+20Z_{parallel} = \frac{\frac{120}{s}}{\frac{6s + 20}{s}} = \frac{120}{s} \cdot \frac{s}{6s + 20} = \frac{120}{6s + 20}Zparallel​=s6s+20​s120​​=s120​⋅6s+20s​=6s+20120​

      Zparallel=1202(3s+10)=603s+10Z_{parallel} = \frac{120}{2(3s + 10)} = \frac{60}{3s + 10}Zparallel​=2(3s+10)120​=3s+1060​

      Simplified circuit:

      V_s(s) = 12/s ---[4Ω]---[60/(3s+10)]--- ground

      Step 3: Apply KVL

      Current I(s)I(s)I(s) flows through series elements:

      Vs(s)=I(s)⋅R1+I(s)⋅ZparallelV_s(s) = I(s) \cdot R_1 + I(s) \cdot Z_{parallel}Vs​(s)=I(s)⋅R1​+I(s)⋅Zparallel​

      12s=I(s)[4+603s+10]\frac{12}{s} = I(s) \left[4 + \frac{60}{3s + 10}\right]s12​=I(s)[4+3s+1060​]

      12s=I(s)[4(3s+10)+603s+10]\frac{12}{s} = I(s) \left[\frac{4(3s + 10) + 60}{3s + 10}\right]s12​=I(s)[3s+104(3s+10)+60​]

      12s=I(s)[12s+40+603s+10]\frac{12}{s} = I(s) \left[\frac{12s + 40 + 60}{3s + 10}\right]s12​=I(s)[3s+1012s+40+60​]

      12s=I(s)[12s+1003s+10]\frac{12}{s} = I(s) \left[\frac{12s + 100}{3s + 10}\right]s12​=I(s)[3s+1012s+100​]

      Solve for I(s):

      I(s)=12s⋅3s+1012s+100I(s) = \frac{12}{s} \cdot \frac{3s + 10}{12s + 100}I(s)=s12​⋅12s+1003s+10​

      I(s)=12(3s+10)s(12s+100)I(s) = \frac{12(3s + 10)}{s(12s + 100)}I(s)=s(12s+100)12(3s+10)​

      I(s)=12(3s+10)4s(3s+25)=3(3s+10)s(3s+25)I(s) = \frac{12(3s + 10)}{4s(3s + 25)} = \frac{3(3s + 10)}{s(3s + 25)}I(s)=4s(3s+25)12(3s+10)​=s(3s+25)3(3s+10)​

      Step 4: Find Voltage Across Capacitor

      The voltage across the parallel combination (which includes the capacitor):

      VC(s)=I(s)⋅ZparallelV_C(s) = I(s) \cdot Z_{parallel}VC​(s)=I(s)⋅Zparallel​

      VC(s)=3(3s+10)s(3s+25)⋅603s+10V_C(s) = \frac{3(3s + 10)}{s(3s + 25)} \cdot \frac{60}{3s + 10}VC​(s)=s(3s+25)3(3s+10)​⋅3s+1060​

      VC(s)=3(3s+10)⋅60s(3s+25)(3s+10)V_C(s) = \frac{3(3s + 10) \cdot 60}{s(3s + 25)(3s + 10)}VC​(s)=s(3s+25)(3s+10)3(3s+10)⋅60​

      VC(s)=180s(3s+25)V_C(s) = \frac{180}{s(3s + 25)}VC​(s)=s(3s+25)180​

      Step 5: Add Initial Conditions

      Now given: vC(0)=2Vv_C(0) = 2VvC​(0)=2V

      The initial condition voltage source vC(0)s=2s\frac{v_C(0)}{s} = \frac{2}{s}svC​(0)​=s2​ is in series with the capacitor impedance.

      We need to go back to the original circuit and add this source.

      Updated circuit with initial condition:

      V_s(s) = 12/s ---[4Ω]---+---[6Ω]--- ground
                         |
                      [20/s]---[+]
                               [2/s]
                         |
                       ground

      The capacitor branch now has total impedance: 20s\frac{20}{s}s20​ with a voltage source 2s\frac{2}{s}s2​ in series.

      This is more complex. Let’s use Node Analysis instead.

      Step 5 (Revised): Node Analysis with Initial Condition

      Let VC(s)V_C(s)VC​(s) be the voltage at the node between R1R_1R1​ and the parallel combination.

      Apply KCL at this node:

      Current from source through R1R_1R1​: I1(s)=Vs(s)−VC(s)R1=12s−VC(s)4I_1(s) = \frac{V_s(s) - V_C(s)}{R_1} = \frac{\frac{12}{s} - V_C(s)}{4}I1​(s)=R1​Vs​(s)−VC​(s)​=4s12​−VC​(s)​

      Current through R2R_2R2​: I2(s)=VC(s)R2=VC(s)6I_2(s) = \frac{V_C(s)}{R_2} = \frac{V_C(s)}{6}I2​(s)=R2​VC​(s)​=6VC​(s)​

      Current through capacitor (with initial condition):

      The capacitor has impedance 20s\frac{20}{s}s20​ and initial voltage source 2s\frac{2}{s}s2​ in series.

      Using the voltage across the capacitor branch: IC(s)=VC(s)−2s20s=VC(s)−2s20s=s[VC(s)−2s]20I_C(s) = \frac{V_C(s) - \frac{2}{s}}{\frac{20}{s}} = \frac{V_C(s) - \frac{2}{s}}{\frac{20}{s}} = \frac{s[V_C(s) - \frac{2}{s}]}{20}IC​(s)=s20​VC​(s)−s2​​=s20​VC​(s)−s2​​=20s[VC​(s)−s2​]​

      IC(s)=sVC(s)−220I_C(s) = \frac{sV_C(s) - 2}{20}IC​(s)=20sVC​(s)−2​

      KCL: I1(s)=I2(s)+IC(s)I_1(s) = I_2(s) + I_C(s)I1​(s)=I2​(s)+IC​(s)

      12s−VC(s)4=VC(s)6+sVC(s)−220\frac{\frac{12}{s} - V_C(s)}{4} = \frac{V_C(s)}{6} + \frac{sV_C(s) - 2}{20}4s12​−VC​(s)​=6VC​(s)​+20sVC​(s)−2​

      Multiply through by 60 (LCM of 4, 6, 20):

      15[12s−VC(s)]=10VC(s)+3[sVC(s)−2]15\left[\frac{12}{s} - V_C(s)\right] = 10V_C(s) + 3[sV_C(s) - 2]15[s12​−VC​(s)]=10VC​(s)+3[sVC​(s)−2]

      180s−15VC(s)=10VC(s)+3sVC(s)−6\frac{180}{s} - 15V_C(s) = 10V_C(s) + 3sV_C(s) - 6s180​−15VC​(s)=10VC​(s)+3sVC​(s)−6

      180s+6=15VC(s)+10VC(s)+3sVC(s)\frac{180}{s} + 6 = 15V_C(s) + 10V_C(s) + 3sV_C(s)s180​+6=15VC​(s)+10VC​(s)+3sVC​(s)

      180+6ss=VC(s)[25+3s]\frac{180 + 6s}{s} = V_C(s)[25 + 3s]s180+6s​=VC​(s)[25+3s]

      Solve for VC(s)V_C(s)VC​(s):

      VC(s)=180+6ss(25+3s)=6(30+s)s(3s+25)V_C(s) = \frac{180 + 6s}{s(25 + 3s)} = \frac{6(30 + s)}{s(3s + 25)}VC​(s)=s(25+3s)180+6s​=s(3s+25)6(30+s)​

      VC(s)=2(30+s)s(s+253)V_C(s) = \frac{2(30 + s)}{s(s + \frac{25}{3})}VC​(s)=s(s+325​)2(30+s)​

      Step 6: Ready for Inverse Laplace Transform

      Final expression:

      VC(s)=2(30+s)s(s+253)=2s+60s(s+253)V_C(s) = \frac{2(30 + s)}{s(s + \frac{25}{3})} = \frac{2s + 60}{s(s + \frac{25}{3})}VC​(s)=s(s+325​)2(30+s)​=s(s+325​)2s+60​

      Or:

      VC(s)=6s+1803s(s+253)=6s+1803s2+25sV_C(s) = \frac{6s + 180}{3s(s + \frac{25}{3})} = \frac{6s + 180}{3s^2 + 25s}VC​(s)=3s(s+325​)6s+180​=3s2+25s6s+180​

      At this point, you would apply Inverse Laplace Transform using partial fraction expansion.

      Deriving Differential Equation from Example 6

      If asked to find the differential equation that corresponds to the s-domain analysis:

      From the Final s-Domain Equation

      We have: VC(s)[s(3s+25)]=6s+180V_C(s)[s(3s + 25)] = 6s + 180VC​(s)[s(3s+25)]=6s+180

      3s2VC(s)+25sVC(s)=6s+1803s^2V_C(s) + 25sV_C(s) = 6s + 1803s2VC​(s)+25sVC​(s)=6s+180

      Apply Inverse Correspondence

      • s2VC(s)→d2vC(t)dt2s^2V_C(s) \rightarrow \frac{d^2v_C(t)}{dt^2}s2VC​(s)→dt2d2vC​(t)​ (with initial conditions handled separately)
      • sVC(s)→dvC(t)dtsV_C(s) \rightarrow \frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}sVC​(s)→dtdvC​(t)​
      • VC(s)→vC(t)V_C(s) \rightarrow v_C(t)VC​(s)→vC​(t)
      • s→ddts \rightarrow \frac{d}{dt}s→dtd​ (when applied to constants becomes derivative of that function)

      For the RHS: 6s+180→6ddt[constant]+1806s + 180 \rightarrow 6\frac{d}{dt}[\text{constant}] + 1806s+180→6dtd​[constant]+180

      But we need to track back to the source. The original source was 12u(t)12u(t)12u(t), so:

      This is complex. The cleaner way: recognize that the differential equation would be derived from the time-domain KCL directly.

      Alternative: Derive from Time Domain KCL

      From the original circuit, at the node:

      vs(t)−vC(t)R1=vC(t)R2+CdvC(t)dt\frac{v_s(t) - v_C(t)}{R_1} = \frac{v_C(t)}{R_2} + C\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}R1​vs​(t)−vC​(t)​=R2​vC​(t)​+CdtdvC​(t)​

      Substitute values: vs(t)=12u(t)v_s(t) = 12u(t)vs​(t)=12u(t), R1=4R_1 = 4R1​=4, R2=6R_2 = 6R2​=6, C=0.05C = 0.05C=0.05

      12−vC(t)4=vC(t)6+0.05dvC(t)dt\frac{12 - v_C(t)}{4} = \frac{v_C(t)}{6} + 0.05\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}412−vC​(t)​=6vC​(t)​+0.05dtdvC​(t)​

      Multiply by 12:

      3[12−vC(t)]=2vC(t)+0.6dvC(t)dt3[12 - v_C(t)] = 2v_C(t) + 0.6\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}3[12−vC​(t)]=2vC​(t)+0.6dtdvC​(t)​

      36−3vC(t)=2vC(t)+0.6dvC(t)dt36 - 3v_C(t) = 2v_C(t) + 0.6\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt}36−3vC​(t)=2vC​(t)+0.6dtdvC​(t)​

      0.6dvC(t)dt+5vC(t)=360.6\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt} + 5v_C(t) = 360.6dtdvC​(t)​+5vC​(t)=36

      Divide by 0.6:

      dvC(t)dt+253vC(t)=60\frac{dv_C(t)}{dt} + \frac{25}{3}v_C(t) = 60dtdvC​(t)​+325​vC​(t)=60

      This is the first-order differential equation.

      Final Summary: The Complete Journey

      PATH A (Most Common): Direct s-Domain Transformation

      1. Start: Time domain circuit with components and sources
      2. Transform: Replace all components with s-domain equivalents (impedances)
      3. Draw: s-Domain circuit diagram (without initial conditions initially)
      4. Analyze: Apply KVL or KCL to get algebraic equation in sss
      5. Initial Conditions: When given, add initial condition sources to circuit and equation
      6. Solve: Algebraically solve for V(s)V(s)V(s) or I(s)I(s)I(s)
      7. Result: Expression ready for inverse Laplace transform

      Key Point: You get an algebraic equation in sss, not a differential equation. The differential equation is implicit.

      PATH B (Alternative): Differential Equation First

      1. Start: Time domain circuit
      2. Analyze: Apply KVL or KCL in time domain
      3. Substitute: Use component relationships (v=Riv = Riv=Ri, v=Ldidtv = L\frac{di}{dt}v=Ldtdi​, i=Cdvdti = C\frac{dv}{dt}i=Cdtdv​)
      4. Derive: Form differential equation in one variable
      5. Transform: Apply Laplace transform using differentiation property
      6. Initial Conditions: Substitute initial values from differentiation property
      7. Solve: Algebraically solve for V(s)V(s)V(s) or I(s)I(s)I(s)
      8. Result: Expression ready for inverse Laplace transform

      Key Point: You explicitly write the differential equation before transforming.

      Which Path to Choose?

      Use PATH A when:

      • Problem says “convert to s-domain”
      • You want to work directly with impedances
      • Circuit is complex with multiple components
      • Exam time pressure

      Use PATH B when:

      • Problem explicitly asks for differential equation
      • You need to understand the physics
      • Circuit is simple (RC or RL)
      • You’re more comfortable with time-domain analysis

      Both paths lead to the same s-domain result!

      The Bridge: Converting Between Representations

      You can always:

      • Take an s-domain algebraic equation → derive the corresponding differential equation (inverse correspondence)
      • Take a differential equation → apply Laplace transform → get s-domain equation (forward transformation)
      • Take an s-domain circuit → work backwards to time domain circuit (reverse transformation)

      Final Checklist

      Before stating “ready for inverse Laplace transform”:

      • s-Domain equation is in the form V(s)=N(s)D(s)V(s) = \frac{N(s)}{D(s)}V(s)=D(s)N(s)​ or I(s)=N(s)D(s)I(s) = \frac{N(s)}{D(s)}I(s)=D(s)N(s)​
      • All initial conditions have been incorporated
      • Algebraic simplification is complete
      • Proper form for partial fraction expansion (degree of N(s)<N(s) <N(s)< degree of D(s)D(s)D(s))
      • Units checked for consistency

      Conclusion

      This guide has covered the complete process of converting time-domain circuits to s-domain analysis:

      1. Component transformations with detailed impedance and initial condition formulas
      2. Two distinct paths for circuit analysis (direct transformation vs. differential equation first)
      3. Complete step-by-step procedures for applying KVL/KCL in s-domain
      4. Methods for deriving differential equations from s-domain equations
      5. Multiple worked examples showing the entire process
      6. Reverse operations for working backwards through the process
      7. Practical tips and tricks for efficient problem-solving
      8. Common pitfalls to avoid

      The key insight is understanding that PATH A (direct s-domain transformation) gives you an algebraic equation in sss, while PATH B (differential equation first) explicitly shows the differential equation before transformation. Both approaches are valid and lead to the same result.

      You are now prepared to:

      • Convert any time-domain circuit to its s-domain equivalent
      • Apply circuit analysis techniques in the s-domain
      • Handle initial conditions correctly
      • Set up equations ready for Laplace transformation or inverse transformation
      • Work backwards to derive differential equations when needed

      The next step after this process is applying the Inverse Laplace Transform, which you mentioned you already have documentation for.
